items.title: poor dnn inference performance on windows10
items.body:
Hello

I am about to deploy an application to a windows 10 system. The system has a I5-9600KF CPU, 8GB ram and a 4GB GTX 1050TI GPU as the systems only graphics card, using CUDA11.
But the performance of doing inference using a small dnn on this system is very poor - it takes about 110 seconds to run the network on seven images (one by one), four times on each image. The images are between 1.2 and 3.8 megapixels, each having a different size, with an average of about 2 megapixels per image.
On he same system, and on the same images, the same program compiled without CUDA, using MSVC2019 and INTEL MKL takes about 50 seconds for the same task, and also about 50 seconds when compiled with MINGW 7.3 and OpenBLAS.
The same program runs in less than 10 seconds on my home laptop (I5-7200U, 8GB ram, with an 4GB GTX950M) with CUDA10 and Ubuntu18.04.
I was expecting the GTX1050TI on the windows machine to be about twice as fast as the GTX950M.
Training works decently on the windows system, being about 8 times faster on the GTX1050TI compared to the CPU with MKL, or about 9 times faster compared to the CPU with OpenBLAS, or about 25% faster than the GTX950M on Ubuntu.
Therefore, I suppose that the CUDA install is not broken.

The network is defined as follows for training (the batch-norm layers are replaced with affine layers for inference):
`layer<0>	loss_mmod	 (detector_windows:(raspi:66x99), loss per FA:1, loss per miss:1, truth match IOU thresh:0.5, use_bounding_box_regression:0, overlaps_nms:(0.1,0.1), overlaps_ignore:(0.5,1))

items.title: using detector on (large) image crashes python with no exception...
items.body:
I've searched online for anyone with similar issues but I've not seen it.  I suspect this is a memory issue but it's a bit odd.

My code, based on the examples from the website, works fine on a smaller image but on the size I would like to use it crashes python.  There is no exception raised.  I'm running windows, and when I execute the code, the line highlighted below is where it stops.  Windows pops up an error box saying that python experienced an error and is closing...

The jpg file for the full image is 49MB.

## Expected Behavior
python code: 
gray = dlib.load_rgb_image("8192x8192image.jpg")
detector = dlib.simple_object_detector("custom_detector.svm")
circles = detector(gray)  # fails here on big image

this should detect many many circles in the image 'gray'

This code works just fine with a cropped piece of the image gray, but the full image is a standard output of another tool so ideally it should also work on this image.

## Current Behavior
There is no error message in the console.  Python crashes with a standard windows information box stating that python experienced an error and is closing.

## Steps to Reproduce
The 8192x8192 pixel image has, roughly, 80,000 "dots" arranged in a grid/array.  Each of these should be detected individually.   The custom detector (and also predictor) was used on multiple images of single dots (there is variation in the dots' "circularity") and a very small grid.

Again, the code works fine on a smaller image (~2300 x 2300 pixels) where it detects roughly 4000 dots.

I cannot provide the exact jpg file.  I can try to create a facsimile if necessary for testing. 

* **Version**: dlib v19.20
* **Where did you get dlib**:  installed via anaconda navigator / official release
* **Platform**: Windows 10, 64bit, 16gb memory
* **Compiler**: python 3.7

I suppose having an method to programmatically crop the image and perform the detection on that cropped image that would also suit my needs but the error on the big image would remain so I would still report it as a bug of some sort...

items.title: Will there be Pre-built binaries that work with python 3.7 and above.
items.body:
Currently, the pre-built binaries for dlib only support python 3.6 and below. So meaning if you don't have CMake or a C++ compiler installed then you can still do: 

pip install dlib==19.8.1 

And dlib will be installed without building and compiling, the only condition is that you must be running python 3.6 or below.

So my question when can we expect a binary for python 3.7. 
Thanks.

items.title: Question: LFW Benchmark results recreation
items.body:
Hi,
First thanks for your work on this project and contribute it to the community! It is awesome! :raised_hands:

My team and I are trying to reproduce your LFW benchmark results with no success.
Searching through the examples and the documentation we found [this example](https://github.com/davisking/dlib/blob/f7f6f6761817f2e6e5cf10ae4235fc5742779808/python_examples/face_recognition.py) that states in the comments that what you did to get the benchmark results "just" extract the features of the relevant images, calculate the euclidean distance and if distance < 0.6 the test result should be 99.13%.
https://github.com/davisking/dlib/blob/f7f6f6761817f2e6e5cf10ae4235fc5742779808/python_examples/face_recognition.py#L11-L14
To get 99.38% https://github.com/davisking/dlib/blob/f7f6f6761817f2e6e5cf10ae4235fc5742779808/python_examples/face_recognition.py#L102

Some issues we encountered during our tries to reproduce these results:
1. DLIB fails to recognize faces in some of the pictures (i can provide a list of such if asked to).
2. If we ignore this files, or try to fix the detection issues by upscaling, using the less "strict" detector api(https://github.com/davisking/dlib/blob/6b581d91f6b9b847a8163420630ef947e7cc88db/python_examples/face_detector.py#L73) we can detect the faces but using the extracted features will cause euclidean distance higher than 0.6 for the same faces.

To some it up, the best score we got was 99.03% (using `compute_face_descriptor(img, shape, 2)`).

Is there a place in this repository, in the dlib.net site that the code used to get the LFW benchmark result is published?
Thanks!

items.title: Different implementation of (equalize_histogram, sobel_edge_detector) compare to OpenCV
Error in Random forest output values
items.body:
<!-- Delete the above instructions and then provide a general summary of the issue in the Title above.  Then fill out the template below.  FAILURE TO FILL OUT EVERY PART WILL RESULT IN YOUR ISSUE BEING CLOSED -->

## Expected Behavior
<!--- Tell us what should happen.  What were you doing?  What part of dlib are you using?  What do you think should happen? -->
I use a `dlib::random_forest_regression_trainer<dlib::dense_feature_extractor>` to create a RF model. It is trained on vectors of 4 variables with nTrees = 20 and Feature subsampling fraction = 1.0. There are more than 100k samples.

Target values are between 0 and 1.2.

I train it with
`auto df = trainer.train(samples, labels);`
I use it with:
`double res = df(samples);`

I think that Random Forest model should predict values inside (or near) the ones used to train the model. But I may misuse it...
## Current Behavior
<!--- Tell us what happens instead of the expected behavior.  If you get an error, include the entire error message in the bug report.  DO NOT POST SCREEN SHOTS.  Paste in the text instead.   If the issue is some kind of build problem, include the entire CMake output along with the error message. -->
I've got *VERY* different values when input values differ a litte. Also I get values out of the range of target values...

For example:
```
Input : 0.584699;0.666667;0.127273;0.7859
model output : -3.4313
Input:
0.584699;0.666667;0.127273;0.7858
model output: 0.922213
```
Here the last input's values are very close but the result is *VERY* different.

items.title: issue while installing it in ubuntu server
Having difficulties on selecting bound box for shape_predictor
items.body: The task is to find 68 landmarks (shape_predictor_68_face_landmarks.dat) of the face on the image on iOS. We've used the methods above: 1. Using dlib hog detector + shape_predictor gives good quality but very slow in part of the detector. (Might be issued with lib compilation, but we've haven't found slowness root yet) 2. Using iOS detector + shape_predictor gives good quality and speed, but on some images doesn't find landmarks, for similarity good face detection. (Almost all bad examples works well in p.1) Landmarking does not work properly similarly on iOS in Python, for the iOS detector bounding box. iOS detector: dlib detector: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5710288/83962625-86099080-a8a7-11ea-8197-33cefcfd8779.png) In our research, we've found that shape_predictor quality tightly connected with bounding box position and size. If we move the hog detector for 5-6% shape_predictor doesn't work as expected. The same thing with the size of the bounding box, for some cases it works well, for some gives bad results. Here https://github.com/davisking/dlib/issues/1290 where was a proposal to use all images as the bounding box, but it doesn't work at all, producing false results. The questions are followed: 1. What is the connection with a bounding box and shape_predictor quality, why small changes in the box give false results? 2. What is the normal time to hog detector on iOS? We've got 3-8 seconds for 800x1200 images with 1 face. It seems slow but we have no benchmark. We've tried to use -O3 and enabling NEON but with no effect on speed * **Version**: 19.19 * **Where did you get dlib**: github repo * **Platform**: iOS / * **Compiler**: XCode

items.title: Dlib frontal_face_detector not providing consistent detections for the same image and code.
items.body:
General Summary: 
I'm 98% certain this has to do with my code, but since it's heavily inspired by the dlib example code and I couldn't find any similar issues on GitHub or StackOverflow, so thought I'd open an issue here. Anyhow, for some reason that I can't explain, the `frontal_face_detector()` behaves inconsistently. Using the same image, with the same block of code, dlib will sometimes will pick up the face and other times it won't. So far it seems to be completely random, but again it's probably something I'm overlooking in the code. 

I've tried to eliminate every bit of deterministic code I can think and I've stripped it down to the block below. 

```
import cv2
import dlib
import os
import numpy as np

video = cv2.VideoCapture('./5s_sample.mp4')

def detect_faces(success, frame):
    """Detect faces in a frame."""    
    # Resize the frame
    #frame = imutils.resize(frame, width=400)
    if success:
        # Convert frame to gray and then Use dlib HOG front face detector
        # Note: The dlib CNN version will give more accurate results,
        # but will require more resources aka GPU 
        
        gray = cv2.cvtColor(frame, cv2.COLOR_BGR2GRAY)
        detector = dlib.get_frontal_face_detector()
        detections = detector(gray)
        
        faces = []
        if len(detections) > 0:
            for d in detections:
                try:
                    l, t, r, b = d.left(), d.top(), d.right(), d.bottom()
                    l *= 2
                    t *= 2
                    r *= 2
                    b *= 2
                    w, h = r - l, b - t
                    cv2.rectangle(frame, (l,t), (l+w,t+h), (0,255,0), 2)

                except TypeError:
                    print(type(self.frame), self.frame)
                faces.append((l, t, w, h))

            faces.sort(key=lambda bbox: bbox[0])
            processed_frame['faces'] = faces

success, frame = video.read()
detect_faces(success, frame)
print(processed_frame)
```

**Env:** 

- Python 3.8.2
- Dlib 19.19.0 (installed via pip)
- Mac 10.15
- OpenCV 4.2.0.34

## Current Behavior

If the issue is some kind of build problem, include the entire CMake output along with the error message. -->

The current behavior is just inconsistent detections for the same image. There aren't any errors and the frame data is, in fact, making it to the detector which I think eliminates opencv (but again I could be wrong). The video itself is PII so I can't share it exactly but here's the stream information.

items.title: interpolate_bilinear makes lab_pixel as grayscale
items.body:
## Expected Behavior
`interpolate_bilinear` should either somehow interpolate `lab_pixel` images, or explicitly fail with descriptive feedback.
While inconvenient, I'm ok with having to convert to `rgb_pixel` before passing to `extract_image_chips()`, though lack of error makes it long to pinpoint the issue...

## Current Behavior
Trying to use images using `lab_pixel`s with `interpolate_bilinear` will cause resulting image to be completely desaturated. The image type will be correct, just all chroma values will be set to 128, with only lighting changes. `interpolate_quadratic` seems to have same pitfall.
`interpolate_bilinear` has two SFINAE overloads checking for RGB or not (=Grayscale). LAB has neither in traits and falls into Grayscale. In theory, checking for 3 channels could work for LAB and interpolating as if it was RGB, although I don't know how chroma (AB) behaves on boundaries when interpolating (my guess is not so great).

## Steps to Reproduce
Use e.g. `extract_image_chips()` on colorful `::dlib::matrix<::dlib::lab_pixel>`. Since `extract_image_chips()` internally interpolates, the color information will be lost.

* **Version**: 19.19
* **Where did you get dlib**: vcpkg
* **Platform**: Windows 10 64-bit
* **Compiler**: MSVC 19.27.28826.0

items.title: How to speed up python code from 11 to 30 FPS or more in the real-time video?
items.body:
I am trying to detect people based on their clothes in real time video and need to speed up from 11 to 30 frames per second (FPS) or more. Unfortunately, it requests 30 FPS at least to work well.

Have any way to speed up it?

When I trained the model, I followed this https://www.hackevolve.com/create-your-own-object-detector/ which used HOG+SVM

**Note:** I have GPU (1050)

Full code after training:

```
import cv2
import dlib
from imutils.video import FPS
detector = dlib.simple_object_detector("clothes_detector.svm")
cap = cv2.VideoCapture(0)
# video dimension in python-opencv
# width = cap.get(3)  # float
# height = cap.get(4)  # float
# print width, height
# time.sleep(2.0)
fps = FPS().start()

while (1):
    _, image = cap.read()

    if _ is True:
        # convert to grayscale
        img = cv2.cvtColor(image, cv2.COLOR_BGR2GRAY)
        # image = image
        # image =cv2.cvtColor(image, cv2.COLOR_BGR2RGB)

    else:
        continue
    # hog_image = detector.detect(image, annotate='texture')

    # Display result
    # cv2.imshow("Original Tracking", img)
    boxes = detector(img)
    for box in boxes:
        (x, y, xb, yb) = [box.left(), box.top(), box.right(), box.bottom()]
        cv2.rectangle(image, (x, y), (xb, yb), (0, 0, 255), 2)
    cv2.imshow("Color Tracking", img)

    # cv2.imshow("kernel", g_kernel)
    if cv2.waitKey(1) & 0xFF == ord('q'):
        cap.release()
        cv2.destroyAllWindows()
        break
    fps.update()
    fps.stop()
    # print("[INFO] elapsed time: {:.2f}".format(fps.elapsed()))
    print("[INFO] approx. FPS: {:.2f}".format(fps.fps()))
```

items.title: Using LBFGS or Levenberg-Marquardt to train neural network
items.body: I am trying to train a two-layer feedforward neural network with a very small amount of data. I have seen that in such cases using a second order optimization method like Levenberg-Marquardt or LBFGS gives better results than SGD or Adam. On Matlab I can easily do it using `trainlm` or `trainbr`. Even though I see that `dlib` has implementations for LBFGS and Levenberg-Marquardt as optimizers, for training of neural networks only SGD and Adam are available. I was wondering if there is any way I can use say the `solve_least_squares_lm` method to train the neural network.

items.title: How-to change the number of classes?
items.body:
Yes, I know, really close to "Why can't I change the network architecture at runtime?", the very first Deep Learning question in FAQ section... but I'm asking some help as well. I think DLIB is great to quiclky develop tools for classification: today digits, tomorrow letters or shapes. But today 10 classes, tomorrow 24 or whatelse. I really need to have a parametrized number of classes because I want to release just one tool. That said, far from asking to change anything in DLIB architecture, could someone give me some hints (links, literature, tutorials) about those "_compile time constructs in C++ you can use to enumerate network architectures (e.g. loop over filter widths) if you really wanted to do so_."? Thank you very much.

Michele.

items.title: Question: Shape Predictor and rotated objects
items.body:
Hello,

this is more like a question than an issue or bug.

I have an object where I want to track several keypoints. For the actual object detection I'm using tensorflow, which works quite good and also detects the object when its rotated in scene. I then use these information (rectangle + image) to feed into the dlib shape predictor to get the keypoints of this object. This works quite well when I train a model where the object is not rotated, but performance on images with rotated object is quite bad.

Now my questions are:
1. Is dlib's shape predictor not made for objects which are rotated?
2. Would it help if I use rotated images/labels during training?

Thanks

items.title: dlib is still using IplImage from OpenCV
items.body:
Recent changes (#1949 and #1963) have been added to work around issues that you can no longer directly assign cv::Mat objects to IplImage. Instead it uses cvIplImage to generate a new one. However, surely that is missing the point: IplImage is deprecated and has been for a while. The removal of the simple assignment is a reflection of this deprecation. For OpenCV4, these declarations still exist but are no longer documented - at least not in the main documentation. The worry is that IplImage will be further deprecated/removed or hidden and this code will be broken.

It would be worth going further and removing the internal use of IplImage at all if cv::Mat is supplied as a parameter. There is a second question as to whether IplImage should be removed from the API - perhaps there could be a build time option to only enable it if required.

items.title: Adapting dnn_face_recognition_ex.cpp for use with full body keypoints?
items.body:
Hi, and thank you for making this lib available!

I am looking to build a person Re-ID application, and am thinking of using an approach based on the example `dnn_face_recognition_ex.cpp`. 

My question is, will I need to re-train a model for this? Or can the `dlib_face_recognition_resnet_model_v1` be used for any set of keypoints? 

Basically, I would find body keypoints in a set of images, and pass them in place of the face landmarks to match them.

Is this a valid approach?

Thank you.

items.title: Doubts about the MMOD examples
items.body:
Hi, I've been reading the MMOD examples several times, but there are things that I think I am missing.

The first MMOD example talks about a receptive field of a little over 50x50.
https://github.com/davisking/dlib/blob/253745d29fd510620a1bcee0add50a7663a9f5d6/examples/dnn_mmod_ex.cpp#L32-L39

However, the network downsamples the image by a factor of 8, and the sliding window has a size of 6x6 in the feature space, which translates to 48x48 pixels in the image space. So, shouldn't this be `a little under 50x50`?
Regardless of that, the objects that we are trying to detect are 40x40 pixels, which certainly fit inside of the 48x48 sliding windows.

In the DNN Face detection example, the network has been modified to detect 80x80 faces.
https://github.com/davisking/dlib/blob/253745d29fd510620a1bcee0add50a7663a9f5d6/examples/dnn_mmod_face_detection_ex.cpp#L27-L33

However, the sliding window is of size 9x9, which translates to 72x72 in the image space (since the down-sampling factor is 8).

I am guessing there is no problem if the object is a bit bigger or smaller than the sliding window.

Finally, in the car detector example:
https://github.com/davisking/dlib/blob/253745d29fd510620a1bcee0add50a7663a9f5d6/examples/dnn_mmod_train_find_cars_ex.cpp#L221-L229

A similar network is setup, so that the receptive field is 72, but in this case the maximum size is 70, which makes more sense to me than the previous object sizes and network receptive fields.

So, I am certainly missing something here.
I was sure I completely understood the relation between sliding window size, down-sampling of the network and min object size when I read the car examples. But when I read the other two previous examples, I had some doubts.

- Am I understanding correctly what the receptive field means in this case?
- How sensitive is the network to the relation between the min object size and the size of the sliding window? In other words, how much bigger/smaller can objects be with regards to the sliding window in the image space? (my guess is that it depends on how we setup the IoU for scoring the detections)

Thanks in advance :)

Edit:
I know that the literature defines the receptive field of a Iayer (or network) as all the pixels in the input image that contribute to the output of the layer (or network), which is computed in the following way:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1671644/79960981-08d5b800-84c1-11ea-9827-b0ac485324fa.png)


where:
- `rf`: receptive field
- `l`: layer index
- `ks`: kernel size
- `s`: stride
And the receptive field of the first layer is directly the kernel size.
With that in mind, the receptive field of the `dnn_mmod_ex.cpp` is:

|layer           | ks| s| rf                                        |
|----------------|---|--|-------------------------------------------|
|1               | 5 |2 | 5                                         |
|2               | 5 |2 | 5 + (5 - 1) * 2 = 13                      |
|3               | 5 |2 | 13 + (5 - 1) * 2 * 2 = 29                 |
|4               | 3 |1 | 29 + (3 - 1) * 2 * 2 * 2 = 45             |
|5               | 3 |1 | 45 + (3 - 1) * 2 * 2 * 2 * 1 = 61         |
|6               | 3 |1 | 61 + (3 - 1) * 2 * 2 * 2 * 1 * 1 = 77     |
|7               | 6 |1 | 77 + (6 - 1) * 2 * 2 * 2 * 1 * 1 * 1 = 117|

So, according to this formula, the receptive field of this network would be 117.

But I think, in the dlib examples, we are just referring to how we map the input and output coordinates of a layer (or network).

items.title: dnn corrupted after failed deserialize
items.body:
Hello

In order to reuse the training time, my application optionally can load a pretrained dnn, to be used usually after updating the dataset. After the last change in the network structure, the training seemed to be working, saving the dnn also seemed to be working, but when I attempted to load the network, it failed, complaining about padding_y being invalid.
As far as I know, there is no guarantee that after a failed deserialize("file")>>net; the network is still usable for training.
Nonetheless, it would be nice if there would be either a guarantee that the dnn is unmodified if deserialize fails, or that it's completely unusable, so that the training fails from the beginning, in order not to waste time attempting to train a network only to find out that it's corrupted and can not be loaded.

items.title: Element wise comparison ?
Dlib + Python 3.8+ Memcached Feature
items.body:
Hello. Tell me please, can Dlib work with Memcached? I conducted a simple test and here is the result:
import dlib
from datetime import datetime as dt

img = dlib.load_rgb_image ("1.jpg")
detector = dlib.cnn_face_detection_model_v1 ("mmod_human_face_detector.dat")
print ("GO", str (dt.now ()))
dets = detector (img, 0)
print ("First start", str (dt.now ()))
dets = detector (img, 0)
print ("Second start", str (dt.now ()))
dets = detector (img, 0)
print ("Third start", str (dt.now ()))

Result:
GO 2020-04-03 14: 12: 38.604230
First start 2020-04-03 14: 12: 39.724455
Second start 2020-04-03 14: 12: 39.735937
Third start 2020-04-03 14: 12: 39.746545

At the first start, the model from the file is serialized and this takes a lot of time. When I try to put a class in Memcached, it throws an error.

items.title: Use of C++17 deprecated feature: std::iterator
items.body:
## Expected Behavior
Compilation with C++17 without issues.

## Current Behavior
Warnings are triggered with new versions of the standard library about the usage of deprecated features.

> C:\DevStudio\Vs2019\VC\Tools\MSVC\14.24.28314\INCLUDE\xutility(974,1): warning C4996: 'std::iterator<std::forward_iterator_tag,double,__int64,double *,double &>::iterator_category': warning STL4015: The std::iterator class template (used as a base class to provide typedefs) is deprecated in C++17. (The <iterator> header is NOT deprecated.) The C++ Standard has never required user-defined iterators to derive from std::iterator. To fix this warning, stop deriving from std::iterator and start providing publicly accessible typedefs named iterator_category, value_type, difference_type, pointer, and reference. Note that value_type is required to be non-const, even for constant iterators. You can define _SILENCE_CXX17_ITERATOR_BASE_CLASS_DEPRECATION_WARNING or _SILENCE_ALL_CXX17_DEPRECATION_WARNINGS to acknowledge that you have received this warning.
>     using iterator_category = typename _Iter::iterator_category;
> ^

## Steps to Reproduce
Compile a small program with MSVC 14.24 (A recent build of VS2019) using matrix iterators

The issue is located in https://github.com/davisking/dlib/blob/d610e56c2ab000f8d129f0ae008f68a3d5597a4b/dlib/matrix/matrix_exp.h#L60

Relevant info about the deprecation: https://www.fluentcpp.com/2018/05/08/std-iterator-deprecated/

Looking in the search, this is the only occurrence.

Note: We were planning to patch this locally, once successful, I'll share a patch.

* **Version**: DLib 19.2 (Also reproducible in trunk)
* **Where did you get dlib**: dlib.net
* **Platform**: Windows 64bit
* **Compiler**: MSVC 14.24

items.title: link to parallel openblas on Fedora/Centos
items.body:
In [dlib/find_blas.cmake](https://github.com/davisking/dlib/blob/c8a175f56901e64d741ac43297d3cece858cd31e/dlib/cmake_utils/find_blas.cmake#L195), dlib looks for the libopenblas.so library. On Centos/Fedora, openblas-devel, the equivalent library to libopenblas-dev on Ubuntu, installs libopenblas.so; however, it also installs libopenblasp.so (among other variants). It is my understanding that the p in libopenblasp.so stands for parallel and this is the version of the library that supports multithreading. The numpy rpm for Fedora, for instance, [links](https://src.fedoraproject.org/rpms/numpy/blob/64fa2c8e7504e7f22fa0672b8838a51848954dea/f/numpy.spec#_130) to openblasp.

So, do you think should try to link to libopenblasp.so first on Fedora/Centos?

I know that it is possible to set the CMake variable cblas_lib to the abs path to libopenblasp.so, but the difference between libopenblas.so and libopenblasp.so is not obvious.

dlib v19.19 (or master currently c8a175f) cloned from here
Centos 7 (Linux 5.3.11-200.fc30.x86_64)
g++ 4.8.5 (ancient, I know)

items.title: Trying to train a Custom FHog Like Descriptor to run in external library
items.body:
## Expected Behavior
I am trying to train a hog-like descriptor using the object detector / fhog_scan_pyramid. 
( I followed these instructions here:[https://github.com/davisking/dlib/blob/6b581d91f6b9b847a8163420630ef947e7cc88db/dlib/image_processing/scan_fhog_pyramid.h#L18]()

and here:[http://dlib.net/fhog_object_detector_ex.cpp.html]( )
The SVM model is then run on piece of hardware that has accelerated support for a hog like feature  (it cannot support FHOG, otherwise I would just use that)

## Current Behavior
In dlib and with testing the descriptor works fine and shows an amazing detection rate and low false positives. When I then take the w vector from the resultant object detector, using this call: [https://github.com/davisking/dlib/blob/6b581d91f6b9b847a8163420630ef947e7cc88db/dlib/image_processing/object_detector.h#L104]() and move it over to my own software  I get vastly different results. At first I failed to account for the padding and was getting out a w that was longer then expected (I missed the part about the 1 cell padding around the search region window size), but now I get out a feature vector of the expected length. 

My question is, from my understanding, when the training / object detection is run, a window is slid across the HOG image (basically an image containing cells of hog-like feature vectors) and the descriptor returned is a row-major vector of each descriptor in the window concatenated with each cell concatenated into a single vector (row wise). I should in theory then be able to in my own code multiply my descriptors with the svm model (w() param in the dlib object detector). 

I am currently trying to understand if I am missing something in the dectect() function call in the object detector and the hog filter-banks that are called in that piece of code. Are there some crucial parts of code I am missing when trying to port this SVM model to my own library? I assumed that this code is an optimization step that speeds up detection, but please correct me if I am wrong. 

## Steps to Reproduce
Train a custom, hog-like descriptor and then try to use it somewhere else assuming the svm vector from get_w() is row major and the svm score is equal to your descriptor * svm_vector


* **Version**: <!-- What version of dlib? --> Pulled the current master
* **Where did you get dlib**: github
* **Platform**: Ubuntu 18.04
* **Compiler**: gcc

items.title: dlib has a couple of inconsistencies with respect to long, unsigned long and int
items.body:
## Expected Behavior
Proper/documented intentional conversion between different integer types.

## Current Behavior
At a couple of positions in the code longs are converted to int without proper casting. While this may be nowadays relatively uncritical (most of the computers are probably running with 64 bit integers anyway), there might be some issues on older machines where (unsigned) long and int have different sizes.
Though, the program might crash anyway on 32bit systems when trying to use too large datasets.

## Steps to Reproduce
1) Uncritical example: string.h
std::setw(int) has as an int parameter but gets passed in pad_int_with_zeros(int,unsigned long width) an unsigned long parameter "width".

2) Critical example: hash
murmur_hash3(_2) uses for the length also an int but both versions of hash pass a value of type std::string::size_type to murmur_hash3(_2) that may be larger than 32bit (even on 32bit machines). This may result in wrong hash values.

A bigger problem might be simple_hash_map, though, because: simple_hash_map()::insert(0xff..ff00000000,0xff..fe00000000,1) calls internally murmur_hash3_2 with a long but murmur_hash3_2 has as parameter types uint32! So, in my example the hash value is definitely wrong!

simple_hash_map()::insert requires that "a" and "b" are smaller than std::numeric_limits<uint32>::max().
The same holds for the methods accessing the hashed value.

PS: murmur_hash3 and murmur_hash3_2 have different parameter types as well!

3) Critical? matrix_blas_bindings.h parameter inconsistencies
The return type of a lot of functions is int (example get_ld) but often the variable used for returning the result is of type long.

Concrete example:
template <typename T>
        int get_ld (const assignable_ptr_matrix<T>& m) { return m.nc(); }

m.nc() returns a long but get_ld returns an int.

PS: I cannot provide a complete list because the list is 296 issues long! But I suspect that there are more..

dlib 19.19
clang compiler on macOS 64bit

items.title: C++20 removed std::result_of
items.body:
**Description:**
In /std:c++17 mode, this triggers a deprecation warning in recent versions of MSVC. In /std:c++latest mode, now that microsoft/STL#380 has been merged, this will trigger an error in VS 2019 16.6 Preview 2.

**Reproduce steps:**
1. git clone https://github.com/davisking/dlib  D:\Dlib\src
2. cd D:\Dlib\src
3. set _CL_=/D_HAS_AUTO_PTR_ETC=1 /D_WINSOCKAPI_
5. mkdir build_amd64
6. cd D:\Dlib\src\build_amd64
7. cmake -G "Visual Studio 15 Win64" -DCMAKE_SYSTEM_VERSION=10.0.17134.0 ..
8. cmake -G "Visual Studio 15 Win64" -DCMAKE_SYSTEM_VERSION=10.0.17134.0 ..\dlib\test 
9. msbuild /m /p:Platform=x64 /p:Configuration=Release Project.sln /t:Rebuild /p:PreferredToolArchitecture=x64

**ErrorMessage:**
F:\gitP\davisking\dlib\dlib\threads\async.h(55): error C2039: 'result_of': is not a member of 'std' (compiling source file F:\gitP\davisking\dlib\dlib\filtering\kalman_filter.cpp)

items.title: Why define DLIB_NO_GUI_SUPPORT by default on Ubuntu?
items.body:
Is there a reason `DLIB_NO_GUI_SUPPORT` is defined in `dlib/config.h` in the version of dlib included on Ubuntu (e.g. 19.10)? This can be seen using:

`cd /tmp && apt-get download libdlib-dev && dpkg -x libdlib-dev* . && cat usr/include/dlib/config.h | grep DLIB_NO_GUI_SUPPORT`

Compiling, say [https://raw.githubusercontent.com/davisking/dlib/master/examples/3d_point_cloud_ex.cpp](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/davisking/dlib/master/examples/3d_point_cloud_ex.cpp), and then following the error message instruction, to "Turn DLIB_NO_GUI_SUPPORT off", a user with su privilege might comment out the relevant `#define` in the system file `/usr/include/dlib/config.h`, but for two of my machines at least, the command `g++ 3d_point_cloud_ex.cpp -ldlib` will still fail, with link errors starting:

undefined reference to `dlib::base_window::set_title(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > const&)'

I am able to clone, build and run dlib and its examples. I only ask as I think this may present a barrier to dlib for some Ubuntu users.

items.body:
I am building a software that uses the dlib face detector as well as facial landmarks. 
The software works fine on my PC, as well as 5 other virtual and physical machines. However, execution fails on one other system where I tested it.

I compiled with Pyinstaller and created a Windows installer with Inno Setup.

##  Current Behavior
Importing of dlib fails on one tested system:
```
# dlib not found in PYZ
Traceback (most recent call last):

  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 219, in _call_with_frames_removed
ImportError: DLL load failed: Eine DLL-Initialisierungsroutine ist fehlgeschlagen.
```
## Expected Behavior
This is the console output on my own system, were it works fine:
```
# dlib not found in PYZ
# extension module 'dlib' loaded from 'C:\\Users\\User\\AppData\\Local\\Programs\\BlinkGuard\\dlib.cp37-win_amd64.pyd'
# extension module 'dlib' executed from 'C:\\Users\\User\\AppData\\Local\\Programs\\BlinkGuard\\dlib.cp37-win_amd64.pyd'
import 'dlib' # <_frozen_importlib_external.ExtensionFileLoader object at 0x00000215B157CB08>
```
## Steps to Reproduce
I am not sure, what is causing the error. My best guess is, building on a newer PC, executing on an older one. I assume it has something to do with the system architecture. It stands out to me that its a Pentium CPU where the execution fails.

CPU used to building: Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-8750H CPU 
CPU of the system were it fails to execute: Intel(R) Pentium(R) CPU 4415U 

I assume the file dlib.cp37-win_amd64.pyd does not work correctly for the third party system.

* **Version**: dlib=19.19
* **Where did you get dlib**: ```conda install -c conda-forge```
* **Platform**: Win 10 64bit (both built and tested on)
* **Compiler**: pyinstaller 3.6

My best guess is, I need to add a different file than dlib.cp37-win_amd64.pyd to make it work on the other system. However, Googling for hours has not told me if I am right, which dll to use and how to make sure this error does not happen on additional systems in the future.

items.title: C++20 forbids inserting inappropriate character types into standard streams
items.body:
The C++20 draft standard incorporates a change to help avoid confusion when inserting inappropriate character types to iostreams. In previous C++ versions, insertion of inappropriate character types into output streams (e.g., `wchar_t`/`char16_t`/`char32_t` into `std::cout`) doesn't result in transcoding of the character, but instead outputs a representation of its integral value. Insertion of pointers to such character types also does not transcode but outputs the value of the pointer. C++20 will add deleted stream insertion operators so that the expression `os << x` will instead be ill-formed when `os` is a `std::ostream` (a narrow character stream) and `x` is a `wchar_t`/`char16_t`/`char32_t` or pointer to such.

We're implementing these changes right now in MSVC, and our automated tests show that your product (or its tests) will fail to compile with these changes in `/std:c++latest` mode unless the "escape hatch" macro `_HAS_STREAM_INSERTION_OPERATORS_DELETED_IN_CXX20` is defined. Specifically, https://github.com/davisking/dlib/blob/master/dlib/test/string.cpp#L148 seems to output a `wchar_t*` to a `std::ostream`.
